questions.text: A 16y girl is brought to the OPD as she has not started her period. The patients 14y sister underwent menarche 2 years earlier and her mother began menstruating at age 13. She has no weight gain, headaches, nipple discharge or abdominal pain. She is not sexually active and is not using any method of contraception. She is physically active and is on her school’s basketball team. Her breast exam and pubic hair are Tanner stage IV. The abdomen is soft. The external genitalia appear normal. questions.text: A 30-year female presents to OPD with secondary amenorrhea. She does not bleed on the progesterone challenge or even after giving her a course of combined estrogen and progesterone pills. Asherman syndrome is suspected. This can result from. Curettage Tuberculosis Uterine artery embolization Cesareans section Cervical biopsy
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A, B, C, D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome is typically caused by intrauterine trauma or surgery (like curettage or uterine artery embolization), certain infections (like genital tuberculosis), and less commonly by cesarean sections. Understanding these causes is essential for preventing and managing Asherman syndrome, which can lead to secondary amenorrhea and infertility
  • ➤ Asherman syndrome is intrauterine adhesions or synechiae They arise due to Surgical trauma to the uterus which may be seen following Dilatation and curettage (esp sharp curettage) Cesarean section Myomectomy where the endometrial cavity is involved Metroplasty Trans-cervical resection of the endometrium Uterine artery embolization Endometrial ablative procedures Intra-uterine infections like tuberculosis and schistosomiasis

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents to OPD with secondary amenorrhea for 2 years. Her BMI is 30 kg/m2. She has no withdrawal bleeding after progesterone or after estrogen and progesterone. The likely cause is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Asherman syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ About Asherman Syndrome:
  • ➤ About Asherman Syndrome:
  • ➤ The diagnosis of Asherman syndrome is based primarily on a high index of suspicion, based on history. In women whose history suggests this possibility, scant or no withdrawal bleeding after sequential treatment with exogenous estrogen and progestin reflects end-organ endometrial failure and corroborates the clinical suspicion. Asherman syndrome is intra uterine adhesions. questions.text: A 30 y comes to OPD for evaluation of absent periods. The patient had a vaginal delivery 8 months ago and she’s not had her period since delivery. Her postpartum course was complicated by secondary PPH requiring blood transfusion and a D & E for retained products. At a visit, 2 months ago, the patient was started on combined OCPs, and she has not had vaginal bleeding. Prior to this pregnancy she had regular monthly cycles. She also has increased fatigue. She is not lactating and is bottle feeding her baby. There is no headache, galactorrhoea, or hot flushes. BMI is 31, vitals are normal. Pelvic examination shows clear vaginal discharge and well rugate vagina. The uterus is small and anteverted. UPT is negative. FSH and TSH are normal. What is the most likely diagnosis?

questions.text: A 20-year-old girl presents to the OPD with excess facial hair for 6 months and delayed menstrual cycles. On evaluation, levels of free testosterone are increased. An ultrasound reveals normal uterus and normal ovaries on USG. The most likely diagnosis is?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Polycystic Ovarian Syndrome

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism. Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Polycystic ovarian syndrome/ disease (PCOS/PCOD) is a disorder of chronically abnormal ovarian function (oligo/anovulation) and hyperandrogenism frequently associated with hyperinsulinemia and insulin resistance, resulting in menstrual irregularity, infertility, and hirsutism.
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD: As per this criterion, at least 2 of 3 should be present :
  • • Rotterdam 2003 criteria is used to diagnose PCOS/PCOD:
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility) Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism) 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • Oligo/anovulation (causes oligomenorrhea, 2 0 amenorrhea, and infertility)
  • • Hyperandrogenism: Biochemical or clinical (increased serum androgens or acne, hirsutism)
  • • 12 or more than 12 follicle 2-9 mm in size present within 1 or both ovaries on USG and/or ovarian volume > 10 mL (pearl necklace pattern).
  • • USG appearance of polycystic ovaries
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • As the patient in the question satisfies first 2 criteria, she is a case of PCOS
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • let's consider the other options:
  • • Option. A. Adrenal Hyperplasia : Adrenal hyperplasia, particularly congenital adrenal hyperplasia (CAH), can cause symptoms similar to PCOS, including hirsutism and menstrual irregularities, due to elevated androgens. However, it is usually diagnosed earlier in life and often has other associated adrenal hormone abnormalities.

options.label: C
options.text: Differentiation of the gonad into the testes

Ans. C. Differentiation of the gonad into the testes

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Normal Sex Development
  • • Normal Sex Development
  • • Sex development starts in utero and continues in adult life with attainment of sexual maturity and reproductive capability Major determinants of sex development are Chromosomal Sex (46XX or 46XY) Gonadal sex (Testes or ovary) Phenotypic sex (External genitalia) Sex determination primarily begins by the presence or absence of the Y chromosome On the Short arm of the Y chromosome, there is located the SRY gene (Sex Determining Region) – Yp11.3 and is the most important genetic aspect for sex determination and its presence or absence determines the direction of gonadal differentiation. SRY activates several other genes that promote testis development. These include SOX 9 Fgf 9 In 46 XX embryos, genes responsible include Wnt4 and Rspo 1. The chromosomal sex determines the gonadal sex (i.e. whether the gonads will become testes or ovaries) in the embryo. The gonads are BIPOTENT (Undifferentiated) till 5 weeks, they then differentiate into testes or ovaries based on whether the karyotype is 46XX or 46XY

questions.text: A 14-year-old girl is brought to the OPD by her mother. She is of normal height, at the top of her class but her mother is concerned because of a sudden increase in hair growth and hoarseness of voice. She also mentions that she hasn’t yet attained menarche. On examination, there is absent breast development and minimal presence of pubic and axillary hair. There is also increased facial hair growth and on local examination, there is an enlarged clitoris. An ultrasound reveals an absent uterus with the presence of gonad-like structures in the inguinal canal. Suspecting 5 alpha reductase deficiency, testosterone and DHT level is done. What is the expected finding in 5 alpha reductase deficiency?

options.label: C
options.text: No change in the testosterone/ DHT ratio

questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • 5 α Reductase Deficiency
  • • 5
  • • α
  • • Reductase Deficiency
  • • Autosomal recessive Karyotype: 46XY Defective conversion of Testosterone to DHT (which is mediated by the enzyme 5 alpha reductase) Testosterone (in fetal life): causes development of the internal male genitalia DHT is responsible for external male genital development: Hence this does not develop as the enzyme mediating the conversion is absent/ deficient Classical presentation: External genitalia: predominantly Female at birth Internal genitalia: Male (The epididymis, the vas deferens, seminal vesicles and ejaculatory ducts form but empty into a short blind vagina) Testis: Located in the inguinal canal At Puberty: Virilization of varying degrees Affected men develop a normal muscle mass, libido, deepening of voice (Testosterone dependent) but have less body hair, less temporal hairline recession, no acne (All these are DHT dependent) Diagnosis: Suspect in infants with genital ambiguity Suspect in adolescence with the characteristic phenotype and a serum hormonal profile showing normal male level testosterone and an increased testosterone/ DHT ratio

questions.text: A 45-year old presents for a routine gynecological checkup. She is having regular cycles with normal flow and mild dysmenorrhea on the 1 st day. She is a non-smoker and has no history of hypertension or diabetes. Her last pap smear was 2 years back which was reported to be normal. An ultrasound shows the presence of a 4 x 4 cm intramural fibroid with a sub-serosal component. She is very anxious and seeks your opinion on what should be done.
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Review ultrasound after 1 year

Explanation:

  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation. Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • This is an asymptomatic fibroid
  • • Asymptomatic fibroids (irrespective of size) do not require treatment and just need an annual evaluation.
  • • Symptomatic fibroids can be managed medically/ surgically/ non invasive techniques based on several factors like the age of the patient, the size and number of fibroids and the location of fibroid
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A: GnRH agonists: This can be given to women with symptomatic fibroids to reduce the size and also control symptoms. It is also given to women pre-operatively to reduce the size of the fibroid Option B: Laparoscopic hysterectomy: There is no indication for surgical managment in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid. Following menopause, fibroids usually shrink in size due to hypo-estrogenism. Option C: Laparoscopic myomectomy: There is no indication for doing a myomectomy in a patient with an asymptomatic fibroid.

questions.text: A 23-year primi is presents at 16 weeks pregnancy with acute abdominal pain. On examination, the uterus is 20 weeks size and there is tenderness over the abdomen. An ultrasound reveals, a 6 cm fibroid in the anterior wall. What is the next best management?
questions.explanation:

Explanation:

  • • This is most likely a red degeneration of fibroid which is commonly seen in pregnancy. Red degeneration occurs in a large fibroid mainly during 2 nd half of pregnancy and puerperium. questions.text: A 34-year nulliparous woman presents to the OPD. She complains of pelvic heaviness. She also mentions that her periods have been increasingly heavy in amount and she has to take a pain killer on the 1 st 2 days of her period due to excessive pain. The periods are otherwise regular. On examination, there is an irregular mass palpated abdominally which is about the size of an 18 weeks gravid uterus. On bimanual exam, the same irregular mass is felt and there is transmitted mobility. What is the possible diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Leiomyoma

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • This patient has symptoms of heavy menstrual bleed and dysmenorrhea which are seen in adenomyosis, fibroids (leiomyoma) and polyp. On examination, this is a fibroid (probably multiple fibroids) The uterus is significantly enlarged and irregular There is transmitted mobility i.e. the mass is arising from the uterus (transmitted mobility is absent in ovarian masses) The woman is nulliparous

Fibroid polyps usually present with inter menstrual bleeding or irregular bleeding In ovarian mass, there usually won't be any menstrual symptoms, also transmitted mobility will be absent (i.e. on moving the mass, the cervix will not be felt to move)

questions.text: A 45-year lady presents with heavy menstrual bleeding for 3 months. On examination, she does not appear to be pale. Her BP is 150/90mmHg. An abdominal and pelvic exam is normal. A transvaginal scan shows a 2 cm Intramural fibroid and an endometrial thickness of 15mm. both the ovaries appear normal What is the next best step?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Endometrial Biopsy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy. It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age. A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause. Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • • At 45y, heavy bleeding during periods could be because of endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy.
  • • It is important to rule out precancerous lesions and cancerous lesions at this age.
  • • A small 2 cm fibroid is unlikely to be the cause of her symptoms but her increased endometrial thickness on the ultrasound (15 mm is a thick endometrium for her age) could be alikely cause.
  • • Th is thickened endometrium warrants an endometrial biopsy to tule out endometrial hyperplasia and cancer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states Women in the peri-menopausal age group with fibroids with heavy menstrual bleeding should be evaluated for endometrial hyperplasia and cancer
  • ➤ Fibroids and endometrial hyperplasia/ malignancy usually coexist as both are hyperestrogenic states

questions.text: What is your interpretation of the following hysterosalpingogram?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Submucosal fibroid

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus. This is most likely a submucosal fibroid
  • • This HSG shows a large well defined lesion in the uterus.
  • • This is most likely a submucosal fibroid
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Let us look at each option:
  • • Option A. Normal : A normal HSG would show a regular, symmetrically shaped uterine cavity without any filling defects or irregularities. The fallopian tubes would be visible, with the contrast material flowing freely through them, indicating patency . No obstructions or unusual shapes should be present.
  • • Option A.
  • • Normal
  • • Option B . Asherman syndrome : This condition is characterized by the presence of intrauterine adhesions or scar tissue. On an HSG, Asherman syndrome may present as irregular filling defects within the uterine cavity or as a generally diminished size of the uterine cavity, depending on the severity of the adhesions.
  • • Option B
  • • Asherman syndrome
  • • Option C. Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block) : In cases of bilateral tubal blockage, an HSG would show a lack of contrast material passing through one or both fallopian tubes ie. absence of free spill.
  • • Option C.
  • • Bilateral tubal block (B/l tubal block)
  • • Option D. Submucosal fibroid : They are fibroids that grow just beneath the lining of the uterine cavity. On an HSG, these would appear as filling defects within the uterine cavity. They might show as smooth, round, or lobulated contours projecting into the cavity, disrupting the otherwise smooth and regular shape of the uterus.
  • • Option D.
  • • Submucosal fibroid

questions.text: Which of the following is the gold standard technique for tubal evaluation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic evaluation

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The following are tests done for tubal patency
  • • HSG (usually a preliminary test) Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard) Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions) Others HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HSG (usually a preliminary test)
  • • Laparoscopic Chromotubation (Gold standard)
  • • Saline salpingography (better for intra uterine lesions)
  • • Others HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HyCoSy Falloposcopy
  • • HyCoSy
  • • Falloposcopy
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Let's review each option:
  • • Option A. Hysterosalpingography (HSG) : This is a radiographic technique where a contrast dye is injected into the uterine cavity, and X-ray images are taken to visualize the uterus and fallopian tubes. HSG is primarily used for evaluating the internal shape of the uterus and the patency of the fallopian tubes. While it's a commonly used first-line investigation for tubal assessment in infertility evaluations, it provides limited information about the external contour of the tubes and surrounding structures.
  • • Option A.
  • • Hysterosalpingography (HSG)
  • • Option B. Laparoscopic Evaluation : Laparoscopy is considered the gold standard for tubal evaluation. It's a minimally invasive surgical procedure that provides a direct view of the pelvic organs, including the fallopian tubes. Laparoscopy not only allows for the assessment of tubal patency (often combined with chromopertubation, where a dye is passed through the tubes) but also enables visualization of the outer aspects of the tubes and the detection of other pelvic pathologies like endometriosis, adhesions, or fibroids that might affect tubal function. Its main limitation is that it's an invasive procedure requiring anesthesia.
  • • Option B.
  • • Laparoscopic Evaluation
  • • Option C . Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS) : SIS involves the infusion of saline into the uterine cavity during ultrasound examination. This technique can be used to asses tubal patency, it also enhances the visualization of the uterine cavity and can be useful in detecting abnormalities like polyps or fibroids.
  • • Option C
  • • Saline Infusion Sonography (SIS)
  • • Option D. Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) : MRI can provide detailed images of the pelvic organs, including the uterus and fallopian tubes, without using ionizing radiation. It's particularly useful in assessing uterine anomalies and some types of fibroids. However, MRI is less commonly used for direct assessment of tubal patency or minor tubal abnormalities compared to laparoscopy or HSG.
  • • Option D.
  • • Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Page 441, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: In treating hypertension, with beta blockers, which of the following semen parameter abnormalities may be seen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Low semen volume

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Low semen volume often simply reflects incomplete specimen collection or short abstinence interval. However, it may indicate partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma. Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)

  • • However, it may indicate partial vas deferens obstruction or retrograde ejaculation. Partial or complete vas deferens obstruction may be caused by infection, tumor, prior testicular or inguinal surgery, or trauma. Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)

Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)

  • • Retrograde ejaculation follows failed closure of the bladder neck during ejaculation and allows seminal fluid to flow backward into the bladder. Retrograde ejaculation is suspected in men with Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Diabetes mellitus Spinal cord damage Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves Medications (β-blockers)
  • • Diabetes mellitus
  • • Spinal cord damage
  • • Prior prostate or other retroperitoneal surgery that may have damaged nerves
  • • Medications (β-blockers)
  • • A postejaculatory urinalysis can detect sperm in the bladder and confirm the diagnosis. If urine is properly alkalinized, these sperm are viable and can be retrieved to achieve pregnancy
  • • Let us explore the options given:
  • • Let us explore the options given:
  • • Option A. Azoospermia : This refers to the complete absence of sperm in the semen. While certain medications and health conditions can lead to azoospermia, beta-blockers are not typically associated with this severe a level of spermatogenic failure.
  • • Option A.
  • • Azoospermia
  • • Option B. Oligospermia : Oligospermia means a lower than normal sperm count. Some medications and health issues can lead to oligospermia, but beta-blockers are not commonly linked to significant decreases in sperm count.
  • • Option B.
  • • Oligospermia
  • • Option C. Teratospermia : Teratospermia is characterized by a high percentage of abnormally shaped sperm in the semen. This condition can be caused by various factors, including genetic defects, lifestyle choices, and exposure to certain chemicals or radiation. Beta-blockers are not known to specifically cause teratospermia.
  • • Option C.
  • • Teratospermia
  • • Option D. Low semen volume (Correct Answer): Beta-blockers can lead to a decrease in semen volume. This effect is thought to be related to the general inhibitory effects of beta-blockers on the sympathetic nervous system, which plays a role in seminal emission. As a result, men taking beta-blockers may experience a reduction in the volume of ejaculate.
  • • Option D.
  • • Low semen volume

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition

questions.text: Asthenospermia refers to which of the following semen abnormalities?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Sperm motility

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Let's go through each option:
  • • Let's go through each option:
  • • Option A. Sperm Count : This refers to the concentration of sperm in a given volume of ejaculate. When the sperm count is lower than normal, it is termed oligospermia. Asthenospermia is not related to the count or concentration of sperm.
  • • Option A.
  • • Sperm Count
  • • Option B. Semen Volume : This is the total volume of the ejaculated fluid. A low semen volume can be due to various causes, including hormonal imbalances or blockages in the reproductive tract. However, asthenospermia does not pertain to the volume of semen.
  • • Option B.
  • • Semen Volume
  • • Option C. Sperm Motility (Correct Answer): Asthenospermia is specifically related to sperm motility, which refers to the ability of sperm to move efficiently. This is an important factor in fertility since sperm must be able to swim through the female reproductive tract to reach and fertilize the egg. Asthenospermia is characterized by a decreased percentage of motile sperm in the semen.
  • • Option C.
  • • Sperm Motility
  • • Option D. Sperm Morphology : This refers to the size and shape of sperm. Abnormalities in sperm morphology (teratospermia) can impact the ability of sperm to fertilize an egg. Asthenospermia, however, is specifically about the movement ability of sperm, not their shape or size.
  • • Option D.
  • • Sperm Morphology

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective

  • ➤ Ref: Page 443, Williams Gynecology 3 rd edition
